raw_text:
Rapper 50 Cent ends protege feud
 
 Rapper 50 Cent has ended his public feud with his protege The Game as the pair said they wanted to be good role models for their communities.
 
 The row blew up when 50 Cent threw The Game out of his G-Unit crew and accused him of being disloyal. A member of The Game's entourage was reportedly shot outside a radio station where 50 Cent was being interviewed. But the pair shook hands as they handed over money to music projects for New York's deprived areas on Wednesday.
 
 The Game, whose real name is Jayceon Taylor, told a news conference: "I want to apologise. I'm almost ashamed to have participated in the things that went on over the last few weeks." Chart-topper 50 Cent, real name Curtis Jackson, said the truce came on the anniversary of the death of the Notorious BIG in 1997, who was part of a volatile feud between the east and west coast rap scenes. "We're here today to show that people can rise above the most difficult circumstances and together we can put negativity behind us," 50 Cent said.
 
 "A lot of people don't want to see it happen, but we're responding to the two most important groups - our family and our fans." The Boys Choir of Harlem got a cheque for $150,000 (£77,800) from 50 Cent, while The Game handed over $103,500 (£53,400). The Game also made a contribution to the Compton schools music programme. 50 Cent announced he has launched the G-Unity Foundation "to help people overcome obstacles and make a chance for the better in their lives".
 
 "I realised that if I'm going to be effective at that, I have to overcome some of my own," he said. "Game and I need to set an example in the community." 50 Cent is no stranger to feuds, with rapper Ja Rule among the targets for ridicule in his songs. On his latest album, released earlier this month, he turned his attentions to Fat Joe and Nas, who have both worked with Ja Rule. Both he and The Game have admitted drug dealing in the past and have both been shot.
llama3.2:1b: Rapper 50 Cent has ended his public feud with protege The Game, citing a desire for good role models for their communities.
llama3.2:3b: 50 Cent has ended his public feud with protege The Game after a series of incidents, including a member of The Game's entourage being shot outside a radio station. The pair met to hand over money for music projects in deprived areas of New York City, citing the anniversary of Notorious BIG's death as an inspiration for their reconciliation. 50 Cent has also announced the launch of the G-Unity Foundation to help people overcome obstacles and make a positive impact on their lives.
gemma2:2b: 50 Cent and The Game ended their feud.  They gave money to music programs for disadvantaged communities.  50 Cent announced a new foundation aimed at helping people overcome obstacles.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Rapper 50 Cent ended a public feud with his protege The Game, which was resolved when 50 Cent said he would apologize for being disloyal to him over the past few weeks.
qwen2.5:1.5b: 50 Cent ends feud with protege The Game, shaking hands after handing over money for New York's deprived areas on the anniversary of Notorious BIG's death.
qwen2.5:3b: Rapper 50 Cent has ended his public feud with protege The Game by shaking hands after a truce was reached on the anniversary of Notorious BIG's death in 1997. They announced they wanted to be good role models for their communities, donating money to music projects for New York's deprived areas and schools in Compton. Both have admitted past drug dealing and shooting incidents. The Game apologized, while 50 Cent highlighted the importance of unity and overcoming personal challenges to make a positive impact on society.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information. It captures the main points of the text without adding any new information or explanations.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to help summarize this text. Let me read through it carefully.

First, the main event is Rapper 50 Cent ending a "protege feud" with his protege The Game. It's about their relationship ending because 50 Cent threw The Game out of his G-Unit crew and accused them of being disloyal. Then, there was an incident where a member of The Game's entourage was shot outside a radio station while he was being interviewed.

They managed to shake hands after giving money to music projects for deprived areas in New York. The Game told a news conference expressing shame but hoping they'd come together as role models. 50 Cent mentioned the truce was on the anniversary of Biggie Smalls' death, who was part of a feud between East and West Coast rap groups.

The pair are responding to the community by highlighting their rise above tough times. The Game received a chunk of money from 50 Cent, and they also contributed to Compton schools' music program. 50 Cent announced launching the G-Unity Foundation to help people overcome obstacles. He made fun of his own past drug use and that of The Game.

So, key points are: end of feud, the incident where 50 Cent threw The Game away, an accidental shooting by a member, then they handed money out, 50 Cent mentioned the truce with Biggie's anniversary, and the foundation for community support. Also, mention both The Game and 50 Cent's past drug problems.

I need to make sure I capture all these points without adding anything extra.
</think>

The pair ended a feud led by Rapper 50 Cent and his protege The Game due to 50 Cent throwing The Game away during an interview. A member of The Game was shot outside a radio station, but they shook hands afterward after handing over money for projects in New York. 50 Cent mentioned the truce on Biggie Smalls' anniversary and highlighted their community role models. The Game received significant funds from 50 Cent, and both have engaged in drug deals. The G-Unity Foundation was also launched to support community growth.
tinyllama:1.1b: Rapper 50 Cent has ended his public feud with protege The Game, promising to help overcome obstacles and make a difference in their communities through the G-Unity Foundation. The pair shored up their relationship on Wednesday by handing over money for music projects in New York's deprived areas. 50 Cent apologised for his "drunken" behaviour, while Game announced that he would donate to the Compton schools music programme after his contribution to the G-Unity Foundation. The two also handed over $103,500 (£53,400) to charity and promised a cheque for $150,000 (£77,800) to The Boys Choice of Harlem. The rappers both confessed drug dealing in the past but insisted they were now seeking help to make it on a more professional level.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The feud between US rappers 50 Cent and The Game came to an end following a public apology from both artists and their own willingness to forgive and be forgiven. The rapper-turned-producer, who had accused his protege of being disloyal, reportedly threw him out of his G-Unit crew and shot the member of his entourage outside a radio station in New York.

However, they have since hand over money to support music projects for New York's deprived areas. During a press conference, The Game thanked 50 Cent for ending their feud and apologized for his actions. The Game has been outspoken about his desire to be a positive influence on the community and has collaborated with other artists such as the Boys Choir of Harlem and Fat Joe.

50 Cent, who is no stranger to public feuds, has launched his own G-Unity Foundation to help people overcome obstacles and make a difference in their lives. The rapper stated that he wants to "set an example" for both himself and other artists in the industry.
phi:2.7b: Rapper 50 Cent has ended his feud with his protege The Game as they wanted to be good role models for their communities. They shook hands after accusing each other of disloyalty, shooting a member of The Game's entourage outside a radio station, and making contributions to the Boys Choir of Harlem and the Compton schools music programme. 50 Cent also launched the G-Unity Foundation to help people overcome obstacles and make a better life for themselves.
orca-mini:3b: Rapper 50 Cent and Jayceon Taylor, also known as The Game, ended their public feud by shaking hands and giving money to music projects for New York's deprived areas on Wednesday, marking the anniversary of the death of Notorious BIG. 50 Cent launched the G-Unity Foundation to help people overcome obstacles and make a chance for the better in their lives. Both he and The Game have been involved in past feuds and have admitted drug dealing, with both being shot.
hermes3:3b: 50 Cent and protege The Game end feud, putting aside dispute after accused disloyalty and shooting incidents, to support music projects for deprived areas.

The two reconciled by shaking hands and donating money to music programs in New York's deprived areas. The Game apologized for his actions, while 50 Cent highlighted the importance of overcoming negativity, noting the truce coincided with the anniversary of Notorious B.I.G.'s death. They donated significant sums to music education programs, and 50 Cent launched the G-Unity Foundation to help people improve their lives. Both artists have a history of feuds and past involvement in drug dealing and violence.

The truce was made on the anniversary of the death of Notorious BIG, a member of their volatile feud between east and west coast rap scenes. Both artists contributed to music projects benefiting deprived areas in New York. Curtis Jackson launched the G-Unity Foundation to help people overcome obstacles and improve lives, while rapper Ja Rule targeted Fat Joe and Nas in his latest album for drug dealing. Both Game and Ja Rule have faced criminal charges related to their past actions involving drugs.
granite3.1-dense:2b: 50 Cent and The Game, former proteges of rapper 50 Cent's G-Unit crew, have reconciled to serve as positive role models for their communities. This truce comes after a public feud that escalated when 50 Cent expelled The Game from G-Unit, accusing him of disloyalty following a shooting incident involving The Game's entourage. The pair met on Wednesday and shook hands, then donated significant sums to music projects in New York's impoverished areas. 50 Cent launched the G-Unity Foundation to aid individuals overcome adversity, emphasizing his own need for personal transformation. The Game contributed to Compton schools' music programs. Both have a history of past drug involvement and gunshot incidents.
